newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA'S IFP WEIGHS RETURN TO CONSTITUTION BODY.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA'S IFP WEIGHS RETURN TO CONSTITUTION BODY.

text.p: Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party was on Wednesday considering a return to the Constitutional Assembly (CA) following two hours of talks with CA chairman and ANC chief negotiator Cyril Ramaphosa.

Ramaphosa, secretary general of the ruling African National Congress, and Constitutional Development Minister Mohammed Valli Moosa headed four-a-side talks with an Inkatha team including Correctional Services Minister Sipo Mzimela.

Inkatha adviser Walter Felgate told Reuters his delegation had made proposals concerned a timetable for the correction of flaws identified by the Constitutional Court and about issues that should be up for further negotiation.

He said Inkatha would decide whether to return to the CA, which is hoping to iron out flaws in the post-apartheid constitution pointed out by the country's top court, after reporting back to Buthelezi. He declined to say when an answer was likely.
"We are seeking to be constructive, but we are seeking to address the essential issues without which our constituency would not allow us to go back," he said.
Felgate said the role of traditional leaders including the Zulu king would have to be included in future negotiations.
Inkatha negotiator Ben Ngubane said he was optimistic that the ANC would make it possible for his party to abandon its 18-month boycott of the constitution-writing process.
"We are worried about the scope of the discussion and also the timeframes...We want room to really address issues, not prescribed by time.
"Our concerns centre very much around the inclusiveness of local government and the responsibilities that the provinces can exercise," he said.
Ngubane said the Inkatha delegation did not renew its demand for international mediation on its dispute with the ANC.

The party quit the CA early last year after the ANC refused to implement a 1994 agreement to submit outstanding issues to foreign mediation and was not part of the May 8 vote to adopt a draft constitution for post-apartheid rule.
The draft was returned by the Constitutional Court last month for further work on a small number of issues, including the definition of local and provincial government powers.
